Had it since June 2015, so closing in on 3 years with it; I feel like I can give it a pretty thorough review. It was also my first smartphone, so I'm relatively unbiased. I'd give it a solid 6.5-7/10. I removed a point for every major fault and a half point for a minor fault. 
 
One major issue, of course, is the bootloop. To my knowledge it was caused by a faulty contact on the motherboard. Took a week to replace, but to their credit it was out of warranty. -1 for that. 
 
The battery life is pretty atrocious and erratic. There have been days where I got 5+ hours of screen on time, and others when I got 1.5-2. You might chalk it up to variations in daily usage, but I pretty much use it for the same things every day. Mostly Messenger (only messenger, facebook app disabled), Snapchat, texting, some web browsing, maybe 10-20 min of youtube videos, 5-10 min of light gaming. Not too heavy, but not light either. Still, other phones do much better consistently in this regard. At times the battery would randomly start draining rapidly even when I hadn't touched the phone in hours. -1 to -1.5 for that, depending on how important it is to you. Classes end around 3-4 for me, by which time it would be at 5-10% battery, so I would just recharge. Keep in mind that it does support QuickCharge, so charging is quite fast.
 
In addition, LG will not be updating the phone past Android 6.0, which basically forces me to upgrade soon. This doesn't really bother me too much though, since in my day to day usage, I don't feel like I'm lacking any features, so -0.5.
 
The last minor issue is occasional slow downs/freezes. Doesn't happen very often, maybe once every few weeks; it is annoying when it happens though, so -0.5 for that.
 
Other than that, the phone is pretty much perfect, both in size and quality. The screen is fantastic, and very high resolution. It is an LCD, which you may or may not prefer over OLED. IMO the colors look very natural. I'm not a huge fan of oversaturation, although I haven't owned an OLED phone before. The Android skin is very light and quite similar to stock. Every day actions are buttery smooth, with no random lags or hitches. The camera is very good, and has lots of manual options. I really like the build of the phone. The bezels are the right size, and the back has a nice texture for a plastic back. The front side really is beautiful. It is also quite durable. I had an Otterbox on it for a while, but I took it off a few months ago because I got sick of it. Since then, I've dropped it directly on concrete multiple times and haven't even had a scratch, let alone a crack.

I bought my G4 at August 2016. Great hardware, especially camera is better than many newer models. Bootloop issue is dramatic failure but I did not face it until now. May be I mostly used as a phone or camera, not for game so no heating. My main disappointment is battery, in 1.5 year battery is dead. Phone is shutting with a low battery warning at %10 percent so I am in danger when I was reaching to %20 percent. I am using two external batteries  for completing the day. From 08:00am to 12:00am main battery discharges then I connect the first external 4400maH battery, at half an hour phone charges and I disconnect the external battery, at 16:00pm-16:30pm phone battery drops to %20 again. Same process reoccurs for the second 4400maH external battery. When turn back my house I am using 3 chargers for charging the all batteries for the next day. I am still waiting nougat for better battery usage but I am disappointed of LG unwillingness or careness of supporting flagship series phones. I will not buy LG again, instead I will buy iphone for their better battery usage.

I have had this phone approximately 20 months for now. On 16th months my phone suddenly stopped working. All signs refer to the infamous bootloop issue. Unfortunately, LG is a very unreliable company in such cases. Instead to take responsibility and repair the phone or replace with new one their so-called official service partners focus on the search for excuses to revoke the warranty. It's very annoying. Otherwise, this device has some quite good features like pixel dense vivid screen, radio and IR port, capable cameras on both sides, and micro SD card support up to 256 GB and phone jack of course. Also, the overall design is unique and the same time pleasing.  
Biggest cons IMO are lack fingerprint reader, outdated OS. Also, battery life leaves to wish for better.

This phone may be old, but for someone like me who's coming from one of the worst budget phones ever made the LG G4 feels like a dream. A friend (who happens to have the same phone) recommended the G4 to me due to it's high res screen, big storage options and phenomenal camera. I can just say that she was right about all of those things, 32GB of space + a 32GB SD Card is perfectly fine for me, I never have to worry about running out of space again, the 3GB of RAM is handy with multitasking, the QHD screen looks AMAZING to me, colors are vibrant and it's bright too! Battery life is not the absolute best, but it's not bad either, and again, coming from an LG Leon which had a 1900mAh battery notrious for being, well, shit, this is a huge upgrade for me. I'll probably keep this phone for 2-3 years until it comes completely unusable, then I'll upgrade to the LG GX series phone of the time. The fact a phone from 2015 is still kicking ass in 2017 and soon to be 2018 is impressive. Nice work LG!

It is 100% sure  it already bootlooped. Dont waste money on battery. Don't waste money to repaire or replace motherboard .Believe me i suffered the same issue. I have read in internet this issue keep comming back even though you replace the board. The only thing you can do is heat the motherboard using an iron to its maxm heat for 15 min( heavy iron is ideal as it apply pressure on chipset while heating). Keep the iron on top of main 2cpu. Then let it cool 30min. Then take a peace of paper and bend it to make thickness same to atm card( may be little more than that). Then place it between display and main chip and assemble the phone. This method works for me for 5days. Then need to repeat.even after this if your phone fail to boot, try with plugging charger. If it boot with charger that mean you have bootloop plus bad battery. I have been using this for 1.5 month using this method.you can find youtube videos to see practically

Hey mate, as far as I know, LG never released G4 models without a risk of hitting the bootloop, they just made a new model to release and discontinued the G4. I actually bought one off of eBay and have copped the bootloop problem within two days. There is a solution that someone threw up on XDA (   ) which apparently fixes the issue. It's to do with the BGA solder on the CPU being of sub-par quality (like XBOX 360 red ring of death and early PS3 yellow light of death) and separating. This guy heats up the solder with a hair dryer to soften it and places a small, folded piece of paper between the motherboard and the screen to place pressure and lower the risk of the solder separating again.

Let me share what has solved my boot loop problem with my LG g4. 
 
I removed the thin metal that covers the motherboard. Then I put a small piece of folded paper  on top of the biggest chip on the motherboard (just thick enough like when you put the metal cover, it would push the chip). Then put the metal cover back on.
 
For me, this is my permanent solution as my LG g4 has been working for a month without having the same issue again.

This is not a Nokia 1020 or an 808, but, that said it is easy on the eye and the pocket has good enough and replaceable battery life and an EXCELLENT camera IF you can be bothered to shoot RAW files and NOT underexpose. AS with most phones the pixels are tiny and cannot stand much underexposure, but its colour and dynamic range when treated in Photoshop is excellent. Its DNG files-which it had from Day one (why I did not get an S6), are excellent because the very fast 24mm equivalent lens is sharp edge to edge and corner to corner. Its jpegs are rubbish-oversharpened cartoon cutout things, ok for web use but little else.
 
There are HUGE bonuses as it has an EXCELLENT RDS hi-definition FM stereo radio that RECORDS everything off air as you would like, OK? You want a complete opera live from the Met? yeah, record it. A Rock concert, no problem, and with the V20 updateinstalled the sound is even better than it was originally. 
The panoramas are very HUGE, but they are just huge oversharpened jpegs lacking in definition and you are stuck with them and the varying exposure across a scene (yuch) nowhere near what an S6 or iPhone 6 plus offer.
 
On the other hand you can always shoot a sucession of Raw files at fixed exposure and then stitch them, but that takes the fun out of what mobile phone panoramas do. I have our postman in three places in one continuous shot! Priceless.
 
All in all, it still up there with the very best> you can do 4ft wide single shots on your wall from Raw at low isos with quality so good nobody will know its from a mobile and not a Canon 1Ds MkII at 400iso!!

I am fairly surprised about written comments for the LG G4. I have this phone for about one year now and I never had a single lag or slowing down whatsoever. Camera is absolutely amazing, speaker is loud and clear and the battery last at least for a day when using the phone hard. I am speaking of about 4,5 - 5 hours of screen on time. I have no complaints about screen, signal and speaking quality when making a phone call. My phone is in the series without bootloop problem. The only thing i think it should be better is video quality, I dont like much how stabilization works, but it's usable when you don't shake it much. Once more, LGs phones are the closest to apple devices when speaking about system stability and smoothness and workflow when using it. I literary haven't restarted the phone for more than 4 months, never did factory reset, and it flyes. There is a lot of negative comments issuing bootloop problem and hating the phone, but rarely anyone will come and write a positive comment if they are happy with the phone. If you have bootloop problem, go and return it, your warranty covers it. For everybody: this phone is amazing, and i recommend buying it, especially now when you can find it for about $300 new.

LG Electronics has been made aware of a booting issue with the LG G4 smartphone that has now been identified as resulting from a loose contact between components. Customers who are experiencing booting issues with their LG G4s should contact their local carrier from where the G4 was purchased or a nearby LG Service Center (www.lg.com/common) for repair under full warranty.
 
Customers who purchased their G4 devices from non-carrier retailers should contact an LG Service Center with the understanding that warranty conditions will differ. LG Electronics is committed to providing the highest standards of product quality and customer service and apologizes for the inconvenience caused to some of our customers who initially received incorrect diagnoses.

LG Electronics has been made aware of a booting issue with the LG G4 smartphone that has now been identified as resulting from a loose contact between components. I was very excited to get this phone but it didn't end up as i expected to say the least.
 
Since 2010 till i got this phone in November 2016, i used only 2 phones, i search well before my buying any device, the HTC Desire HD was my first, over 2 years with it i switched to Nexus 5 in December 2013, the nexus was the best device i ever used to say the least, i broke the screen in an accident hiking, and since we don't have spare parts in egypt, i decided to get a new phone, it was time already, i was focused on Lg as my experience in the Nexus was beyond amazing, the LG G5 was just launched when i bought my phone, but i got a decent price for the G4 and i got it.
 
The phone looks pretty cool, not very slippery like other phones which is a smart design feature, the screen is bright, clear, it's one of the very few phones now that has pointed curvy edges making it unique and pretty.
 
The UI has pretty smart features as well, not worth mentioning as everyone already knows them. Yet it's laggy, i've been habing serious issues with the UI and i need to restart my phone at least 3 times a week, and probably 2 times of those i have to remove the battery to force close (thankfully) in my experience with the Nexus 5, it only happened once in 3 years! with the G4 it happens almost once a week, my phone is up to date so there is no excuse for that...
 
The battery's life is equivlant to my Nexus 5 after more than a year of heavy usage, and this phone just consumes battery, i recharge the phone at least twice a day and sometimes few more quick charges to keep me going, with average to minimum usage.
 
The phone heats up faster than average and it does not qualify to it's stated processor speed. Please note that i got the phone in November and it's March now, so basically the heating was in the winter, i have no idea what will happen in the summer.
 
I am very disappointed with this phone, but i also have to say that i have tried and used other LG models and they were all quite amazing! LG will still remain on top of my list when i look for a new phone, but this model is really a product that doesnt meet expectations.

I bought my Verizon G4 off of eBay in the summer of 2016. The unit was only about 4 months old and was a victim of the dreaded bootloop. However, I was able to get it repaired by LG for free. The phone replaced a Galaxy S4. It is a superior phone in every way. The Marshmallow battery drain issue has been resolved (this affected my wife's Galaxy S5 so it's not a problem unique to the G4) and I almost always make it through the entire day with 20-40% left as a moderate user. It charges very fast in under 2 hours. I love the screen. I can see why this phone would be superior to the Galaxy S6. If you are considering purchasing this unit used make sure that the system board has been repaired and you will have a premium phone for a great price.

I've been using this for more than a month. Hence it is not a long term review. However few pointers for potential buyers: 
1. Great performance. Fluid. 
2. Has more than 1gb memory free at any time. 
3. Battery lasts a day easily with 2 mails sync(off & Personal), whatsapp and a lot of calls, Net browsing, you tube and saavn. But you will have to charge it every end of day. However the phone had excellent standby. 
4. Excellent screen. 
5. Loud speaker volume, though not htc class in sound quality but louder than htc one m9. Bluetooth connectivity very stable and clear for calls. 
6. Powerful hotspot. 
7. Fantastic natural sounding music through my sennheiser. 
8. Most important - exceptional Reception of signal and great call quality. In my case out catches 4g at a place where htc and BlackBerry failed. 
9. Best camera I've seen till date on a smartphone (i've seen Apple iPad air, 5s, samsung s6, j7, one m9 and BlackBerry z30), back and front. 
10. The phone gets a bit warm with games like angry birds our plants vs zombies. Haven't tried other high end games. But that happens with most of the powerful phones per my experience.
 
I bought a htc from eBay for about 18.5k which got conked off in a month and the seller provided me lg g4 as replacement. 
 
The risk of boot loop is there. It also doesn't have fingerprint scanner. Os is efficient but you'll not get a lot of themes. So launcher is the way to go. Overall the phone it's very likable. I thought off writing this cause I didn't plan to buy this but landed with it accidentally. Next time onwards I'll definitely keep lg in mind while buying a smartphone.

LG G4 is a great phone, but beware of the bootloop issue plaguing this phone. If you are planning on purchasing one, I recommend confirming the manufactured date of the phone first. You would want one that was manufactured as recent as Sep. 2016. I think a way to confirm this is by looking at the first three numbers of the Serial number of the phone (found in the battery compartment area of the phone). The serial number for one manufactured in Sep.2016 should begin with '609' (not 100% sure, but you get the idea). I hope this helps.

I would NOT recommend this phone. I have used LG once before, with the LG g flex, and loved it, but this phone has been a disaster. 
 
The battery is absolute crap. It dies quickly and charges slow. It gets super hot with very little activity, so hot that I couldn't keep a case on it or it would quit on me (which is dangerous, because I'm very clumsy). 
 
And just a few weeks ago, it died on me entirely. It was fully charged and I was messaging back and forth with a friend on Facebook and all of a sudden it froze, then went black. I tried turning it back on but it would not move past the startup screen and got so hot that I could no longer hold it. 
 
So I filed an insurance claim and got a new one, everything new except for the back, and I'm starting to experience the same issues after just a couple of weeks. 
 
I usually hear good things about LG products, and maybe this is one of those rare outlier cases that doesn't happen often, but it happened to me and I've had absolute hell with it. Again, I would NOT recommend. I'll be switching away from LG as soon as possible.

And the problem is not the variant, it's the serial number, majority of bootloop phone have serial number starts with 505 to 509 (first digit is the last digit of year manufactured, then the two digits are manufacturing months). One user here will tell you there is no problem, but all other users will tell you don't get this phone. Google g4 bootloop and you will see.  
If you insist to get one, recommendation is:  
1. Get an EXPENSIVE G4 from proper retail outlet that comes with 24 months warranty, and make sure it will cover bootloop issues. Do not get it on internet, most don't come with warranty.  
2. Do not root or unlock the bootloader, LG will void your warranty.  
3. Continuously sync your data on cloud as back up to prepare bootloop comes up anytime.  
4. Have a back up mobile phone so you still can use it when the G4 dies.

I have had 3 replacements between 24 December 2015 through August 13, 2016.  The same issue the phone shuts off, comes on to the LG logo with a sacarstic comment, 'LIFE IS GOOD' when the phone's life is NOT.
 
LG just needs to recall all the G4s and replace them with the G5.  Same hardware/software failure with phones manufactured before and after the release date.  They will continue to replace motherboards/software and count on the devices holding up after the 12 month warranty.
 
When they do replace the returned phones, the replacement sent to YOU  has a 90 day warranty, so if the phone dies again after 90 days , you better have over $200 to take a gamble and purchase a phone from another manufacturer.
 
I was never a fan of iPhones, but I am beginning to lean towards an iPhone after seeing how many Android phones from ALL manufacturers have a short shelf life compared to Apple, and how they continue to patch up the failed phone sent in for service to return to you with a short 90 days warranty.
 
Google Nexus is a better Android choice, but, I am not impressed with the reviews for the camera and you can't add a memory card to back up your pictures when you are low on cloud space or in a location where there is limited or no data or the phone just took a dive in water.
 
The BEST alternative is a Samsung, but again, Samsung's and LG's downside is the bloatware and they are very slow and if there is an Android OS update 3x in 3 years you are only lucky to get ONE.  Apple will update your OS up to 4x over 4 year annual OS updates.

I came across this site and I thought I'd post my experience.  I think the LG G4 is a great phone.  I have the LS991 for Sprint, and I use it for Freedompop.  After the latest Sprint update (ZVC), the phone has much better battery life, and I went back to using the stock battery and back instead of an extended battery. 
Also, I wanted to let others know that I got the boot loop issue in July after buying the phone off ebay in January.  I thought I'd give LG a shot at repairing it out of warranty, or at least I could turn down an expensive repair.  I sent it in (proof of purchase was "bought on ebay") and within a couple of days, they were sending it back to me with a new motherboard!  It didn't cost me a cent, not even the initial shipping because they sent a label.  So, try them first, before giving it up.  It works great now!
Also for those with h815 eu version update it to latest update which was released 2 days ago via OTA. It contains security updates and battery seems a little better on it.

For the people with the boot loop problem on the G4. It's a motherboard issue, factory reset will not help. If you want to back up your stuff do this, (I know its crazy but it works). Take the battery out and grab a hair dryer, use the hair dryer on the phone to heat it up, once it gets hot enough (says 5-7 mins) put the battery in and boot the phone, you'll be able to keep it on long enough to grab anything you need. If you need to backup the whole thing, keep the hair dryer running while you use LG Bridge...

I bought it immediately, fell in love,  I have had good experiences with previous Lg Phones. 
Bought it on 6/5/2015 everything was great,  I started reading news on the media you tube about a boot loop problem of this g4. especially the series numbers with started 505 to 508. The many testimonies written and in videos were shocking and they were pretty sure that if you own a phone with this beginning serial numbers you will have this boot loop motherboard problem for sure sooner or later.  People recommended to save backup the info and media as fast as you can, because is was going to happen for certain.  The phone will die.  
So I was more than worried because mine serial # start 505,  then suddenly, one saturday june 11 2016 a year after I bought it, at night I plug to charge the phone and in the morning the phone was black dead no response. I took the battery out reinsert it press the on bottom and the phone started rebooting from black to the lg life is good log then blank in and endless loop.  Nothing opens no application, no Att, logo nothing.   
ATT store could not do anything to revive this phone , so they instructed me to make a repair request to the manufacturer LG.  so I did. you need to have your original receipt, and in there has to be IMEI#. They took the information and now is has been a week waiting for these prepaid shipping labels to send them my dead phone. 
If you have this phone check your serial number and cross your fingers because there is 99,9 % possibility the motherboard will break internally and your phone will be boot loop rebooting circle.  And if your is an international unlock one you will be refereed to LG Korea and that wont be easy. 
Do not buy this phone, the boot loop rebooting problem is real!!!Mother board problem is real and LG knows it , has recognized it and are willing to service those with in the year of guarantee.

i have had my LG G4 phone for 11 months. Today, I was listening to music while cutting the grass, and the phone froze. I tried removing the battery for a hard reset, but that fixed nothing. It was stuck in some kind of startup loop between the lg screen and the att globe. I looked up the problem online and it seems like this has become a fairly common problem. 
After being interrogated by lg "customer service" and we determined that my phone was "in perfect condition" (said the att employee helping me) and not damaged by water I was told I would have to wait 5-6 business days for a replacement phone or I could pay $15 for 1-2 day express shipping. Why should I have to pay more money when it was their fault and still under manufacturers warranty? 
Anyway,the reason why I'm so pissed off at the situation is that I am going to lose everything on my phone that wasn't backed up to social media. This includes contacts, game data, and most importantly pictures including some very special moments from the first 3 months of my daughters life. I am willing to take some of the blame for not backing up important items to my google drive or somewhere else. But in my defense, you shouldn't have to worry about a phone all of a sudden ceasing to function after so short a time without any notice at all.  
i do not live my life through social media, so the vast majority of my special moments I've shared with my family in the last year may be gone. I'll always have my memories, but over time those will fade, replaced by more happy memories. Pictures are timeless.  
I have always had good fortune with LG products, and have been willing to recommend them to people asking my opinion. I can say that after today, I will never buy another LG product again, nor will I recommend their products to family and friends. I do not want a situation like this to happen to anyone else, especially those that I care about. That's why I am posting this today.

As a former G2 and G3 user, I've decided to stick with LG and got my G4 few days ago.  
Ive received it with LP and immediately upgraded to MM over OTA. 
First impressions: 
+ Screen is the best one I have ever looked in. Bright, pleasant for eyes, and noticeable better then on G3. 
+ Phone runs without any lags. Everything is smooth, responsive and fast. 
+ Camera is awesome, and basically the main advantage of this phone. 
+ Battery life is around 20% better than on G3 ( as advertised). After three charging cycles,  SOT  was 5h 14min (with 60% battery usage by screen and with 5% left). My screen is on auto brightness, and I've spent a lot of time outdoors taking picture, so screen brightness was above average.  
- Phone design is just not what I've expected. G3 looks and feels better in hand, and G4 with plastic back cover is a step back. It is not ugly, but somehow I've found it "boring". 
- For advanced users: bootloader is locked, and can be officially unlocked just on EU version (H815), with permanent loosing of warranty. It can still be rooted, but with locked bootloader installing of custom ROM-s is impossible.  
Regarding bootloops issue, it is officially recognized by LG as a hardware malfunction, but it is not affecting large percent of the units. If that would happen. no carrier , especially in US would not offer this model to its customers, knowing that they will end up with bricked device. 
So, final words: this is an excellent phone, and I haven't regretted a minute for buying it :) Highly

Out of the two phones i would still go for the LG G4. 
The battery may only last a day, the camera may have 5 megapixels less and the phone may heat up a little bit more than the Z3 but in my opinion the LG G4 wins. 
The UI is a re-skin of the android but it's a good re-skin, the camera has far superior low light performance even in video mode, you're getting a 2k screen, a choice of leather backs and other back covers and colours, the phone fits SO WELL in the hand compared to the Z3 and If you don't like some of the G4's app's or LG's keyboard then you can just download other keyboards and re-skins form the app store. 
I think you're getting more with the LG G4 than you are with the Z3. 
If you're looking for 2 days worth of battery then the Z3 is meant for you. 
But if you want a better camera, 2k screen, replaceable battery, leather backs etc etc 
go for the LG G4. 
 
I've never been more glad to pick it as my first contract phone. I don't think you'll be disappointed with the phone either.

It's an issue that occurs (as far as I can tell) , to some devices that are upgraded from 5.1 to 6.0 through bridge mostly, but I cannot tell if some of them got an OTA Update. As far as I am concerned, this bootloop's cause is software. The first one , which was hardware related, was fixed through the new versions of the phone. But some issue occurs and I strongly believe it has to do with the update and LG's rom and drivers.  
It occurs while trying to connect to many wifi's with low signal , and then try to switch to 4G Or 3G network. That happened to about 10 people here in Greece (a really small amount ) , and all of them had the same issue. I , nearly every day, switch wifi's and 4G , and nothing happened to me, so I believe is out of luck , and how the update "sits" on the phone. If we suppose that many million devices are sold (over 20mil. ) and 10K devices seemed to have this problem , the percentage is fairly small.  
LG doesn't seem to work for a solution (yet), and me and some friends are trying to figure out what's going on with some devices.  
Other that this peculiar thing, this phone is excellent all the way!

I have an H812 variant. (Canadian)
 
First and foremost - DO NOT UPGRADE TO MARSHMALLOW (Android 6.0)
 
The latest update overdrives the GPU and I think the Android battery saving features conflicts with the LG battery saving features.
 
I find the phone run HOT and drains the battery super fast with Marshmallow. (Especially when running games) 
Just passive (on Airplane mode) and forcing close all APPs and Stopping all APPs running under "Battery and Power" in the settings menu, screen brightness at 75%, the phone would drain at about 7%  to 10% every hour.
 
I downgraded by flashing Android 5.1 (Lollipop) and the phone runs cool again. No battery drain issues. I would have the battery sit above 95% before lunch time and that's not even on Airplane mode.
 
So trust me when I say, DO NOT UPGRADE TO MARSHMALLOW with this phone. It makes the phone worst. Keep it at Lollipop.

The only possible glitch you can find , is this boot loop stuff some people get into , but the issue can be resolved with hard reset. This can be a possible software issue , lg will fix, but it doesn't happen to everyone. Other than that, battery life is average, considering that you get a 2K screen. Screen-on-time can be about 4 to 5 hours , depending on your usage. If you can call this a drawback, you name it :)  
Other than that the phone is smooth at everything you do. If you get a phone which has android 5.1 in it, you can instantly update to android 6, but after doing so, you must do a factory reset , to make the things better. If it's already on 6, you can set it up from the beggining. Everything is fine, camera is really nice, UI is average (I don't like LG's UI), and phone call quality is excellent. Sound from its speaker is loud, but not crystal clear. Not bad either (I am nearly satisfied). One good thing is that you can place the onscreen buttons whenever you like (you can reposition them , or add more buttons). You can adjust screen colours , you can do practically everything. There's no fingerprint scanner, or quickcharger (but I think it supports Qualcomm's Quickcharge 2.0). And that's all I can think of right now, hope that helped.

Do a hard reset. Pressing vol down and power key simultaneously and a menu will pop up. It will tell you can hard reset. This will power up your phone after it finishes but everything will be deleted. After that try NOT resetting your phone contacts or/and apps from google, and not directly to connect to any wifi networks. Do this AFTER you set up your phone as new. This maybe will work.

See you are running a quadhd display so dont bother about the battery life. I updated to marshmallow and things are very good in the battery dept due to the doze feature. I use a jabra storm bluetooth all day with my g4 & my celluar data on most of the time and along with some moderate usage it lasts me a day. But at the end of day it will less than 20% battery. This is a good phone and if battery matters all that to you, i suggest u get a spare battery along with lg battery cradle or a powerbank or you and buy a 3rd party bigger capacity battery from zerolemon(8500mAh) or mugen(6200mAh). Obviously these battery will imcrease the thickness of your phone but it will solve your battery issue for sure. Reviews of these batteries suggest that they will easily provide 2days backup with heavy usage,but they will take almost 6hrs to charge. So i hope i have made it simple for you to choose..its all about what u prefer

If you set this up right, you can get the best out of your battery. Let alone it's removable, and that's convenient for the most people out there! 
You got definitely 4 hours sot.  
I got my brightness to auto (works well) , and I don't much play games.  
I have WiFi always on. Sync on. And I change to 4G/3G just whenever I want (I have the option "only gsm" , for better signal reception). So that's the way I get always more than 4h sot. I got 5h 15m sometimes, while my battery is at 5% . But I don't really care, as I charge it when it drops to 15%. In android 6.0 it also have outstanding performance idling (when screen is off). Over 8 hours and I got no more than 1% battery loss!!! The phone is also butter smooth. 
To be honest, the bootloop problem , is so overstated, that I cannot understand. And it's not a hardware issue any more, as the first parts of it were replaced. It seems like it is software that can be resolved. Many statements refer to reseting the phone from google, makes it cause boot loop. Just like changing instantly from wifi to 4G. Strangely, i have done the above, and no problems occured. It's a hit&miss thing, and I believe LG will fix it soon enough. I will e-mail them really soon to ask if they plan an update.  
Thanx for reading

I recently gave up my iPhone4 for LG G4, because of being able to remove battery and mostly for the ability to add extra storage. A big plus for me. I was so tired of never having any space left to get an app or even to take a photo. I love the G4, It's fast, has a fantastic camera, and the colors are bright and vivid. I like the feel of the curved back and how it sits in my pocket, but a little frustrating if you want to set it down on a flat surface and use the phone as it wobbles. The only regret I have is that Android is missing some of the apps that I loved. Plus, any apps that I paid for on ios, I no longer have with Android, unless I purchase again. Android does have many more to choose from, and I'm working my way through them to find ones that I love just as much, but a bit of a challenge for some. The operating system is easy to work through and get used to, but can't have multiple tabs open on my browser, like I could on my iPhone.(Or at least I haven't figured out how just yet) Overall, a few bumps, but still happy with my switch.

In the short time I have owned this G4 which was an upgrade from the G2, I can't find anything in particular which isn't that bad. I will be replacing the backcover with something more sturdier and less likely to suffer from cosmetic damage. 
 
It may not have the Snapdragon 810 or the heavily anticipated 820 chipset however it does me just fine. Call quality is clear to the point I have to check people are still on the same call as me sometimes. 
 
Basic functions work well as expected and the laser auto focus on the camera is excellent compared to other mobile telephone cameras I have used. Very clear, colour accurate and good use of contrast.
 
The UI of the LG software is simple, efficient and easy to use. There's not much lag between apps and the dual screen feature could come in handy for some things although I haven't found a use as yet.
 
The option of up to 200GB external storage is also a boon. There's very little to be disappointed about here. If you are a gamer you may want to look at the 810 or later for better performance.

The charging is even faster if you are charging the battery from in middle. Say, you plug the charger when battery was 10%, it will charger from 10% to 90% in almost 1 hour. Charging takes almost 30 mins time from 90% to 100%. Hope this clarifies.

I just had the most exasperating 20 minutes with LG, the people that make my cell phone. The model I have came out less than a year ago and it has a one year warranty. The cord for the phone charger crapped so I just spent 20 minutes on the phone trying to tell the rep. that this phone has got to be under warranty because it hasn't even been out a year yet and it has a year warranty. Then their rep. wants a receipt for a phone that hasn't even been out a year with a year warranty to prove it's within the warranty period! Unfortunately I no longer have the reciept (My fault). Then this man while still insisting that we need some information that is contained on the receipt starts to get even more nasty when I ask him what information he needs. He tells me he needs the IEI number so I tell him I have it since it's on the phone. After he hits that dead end he then tells me he needs the model number which I tell him is also on the phone so I could provide him with that as well. At this point it gets even worse when he tells me he needs the receipt to find out which model cord it is. 
 
Having had just about enough of this person after that obvious lie since there is only one model cod I ask to speak to a supervisor. After about just enough time for the original representative has had enough time to tell the next person who gets on the line what he has told me She gets really nasty and tells me there is nothing she can do and wants to know if there's anything else she can do for me. Needless to say I told her no and hung up.
 
Fast forward to today:
 
Realizing that these people have absolutely no comprehension of what customer service is I just decide to go ahead and purchase a new one from LG since only original equipment will work with the quick charge feature in the phone, so I go to LGs website with the intention of ordering one. After quite awhile I finally find the parts ordering page and try to order and pay for one. At this point the website tells me that they do not sell this cord and gives me the phone number to their parts distributer who promptly informs me that they don't stock that part and that I need to order it from LG, the people who just told me that they don't stock it.
 
So here I go back on the phone with what I now refer to LG's lack of service service department and once again request to speak to a supervisor. This turns out to be the nastiest person that I have ever had to deal with in my life! When I tell him that I would like to speak to his supervisor he tells me that he is it and there is nobody above him for me to talk to. Being relatively certain that this obnoxious man is not the CEO or president of LG and when I asked him if he was he lost it and started to scream and curse at me. So ended that conversation.
 
I have just got off the phone with Verizon who has provided me with some contact information at the LG Corporate Headquarters in the USA and am hoping they return my call after leaving the corporate level customer service head honchos a message. The only bright spot in this whole fiasco is that Verizon informed me that while it is not original LG equipment they now carry a replacement cord which they have tested and it does conform to the requirements for fast charging and they are sending me one free of charge.  
 
Stay tuned.

I have the same dilemma as well. I checked reviews, tests & comparisons of the two phones and its differences need a lot of consideration. Considering the tech specs and features of the two phones I'd go for A8, unless you really want the leather and special manual mode of G4's camera.

Both phones are great but one phone lacks something which the other phone has..
 
Performance: Both have 3GB ram but M5's clock is 2.0ghz plus it has 2 more cores (though i don't think you'd really be able to use all 8 cores). WINNER: M5
 
Camera: M5's main cam is 21MP while the front cam is 13MP but that does not necessarily mean it produces the best picture IMO taking 21mp photos is not wise since it will eat up your phone's storage and uploading it would take so long. I tried the M5's 13MP front cam and if you love taking selfies I don't think 13MP is something you'd go for since it literally shows every imperfection on your face. On the other hand, LG G4 has lower aperture, but it doesn't necessarily mean that it produces better lowlight picture. In my own experience, lowlight shots of G4 are a bit noisy, You may want to take advantage of the special DSLR-like Manual mode to adjust shutter speed and other settings to produce the best photo possible. WINNER: Depends on your camera usage.
 
Display: Personally I'm not a fan of M5's screen display. Compared to smartphones nowadays the screen size of 5" is somehow small. Plus the brightness is not something I like given the dull UI of Xperia phones. I haven't seen LG G4 in full brightness setting but the UI of LG has rich colors which I like. Xperia's UI looks very neat but a bit complicated to use if it's your 1st time having a sony phone since it doesn't seem to be a cliche android looking phone.
 
Physical Appearance: Unlike M5 and most smartphones , G4's back cover is still detachable which allows you to replace the battery easily if you'll have a problem with it in the future. M5's overall appearance looks very simple and neat w/o a case but doesn't feel expensive since it's not made much out of metal. Putting case on the phone makes you think it's the premium Z series since the front looks the same, except the front camera. On the other hand go for G4 if you want the leather for a more sophisticated look. Just make sure you take care of the leather. So far feedbacks are good regarding the leather cover.
 
Water resistance: M5 is well known for being water resistant but even the site claims that the phone can NOT be used underwater unlike some early xperia phones. If that's the case I think G4 can also manage some spilling of liquid as long as it's in the front part of the phone. Just make sure the speaker and the edges don't get wet to avoid damaging the inside and the sensors.
 
Hope this helps you.

t's a 2K display and a powerful SoC, what do you want? I own a G4, I am coming from a Samsung and I'm not a fanboy, I am looking for what best suits my needs. Tell me do you find the other flagships better? The Galaxy S6 is closest in terms of functionality and quality and what? It has reportedly terrible battery life. Other phones have 1080p displays like the Sony flagships before Z5 and still are only slightly better. Bear in mind that Chinese cheep flagship killers are not available everywhere in the world, so we are talking about the worldwide selling brands only. You will always have to sacrifice something in one phone over another. You want 2K? You want best camera? You want best SoC? You want it all-metal? You want almost no bezels? You want it 5,5 inch but to be as small and light as possible? You want it with replaceable battery? You want external SD? You want 3000+ mAh battery? You can choose only few of all this in one device, because that's how far technology goes - some of these options are incompatible with each other. That's why you search for a phone that suits your needs. Flagships are phones full of compromises that are hidden behind gimmicky options that are just dust to the eyes. Some flagships are more balanced like the G4, others are strong in one or two things and weak in another things. You can't have it all. But you can have exactly what your lifestyle demands if you just stop thinking "I need a flagship" when you don't actually need one, especially if you need battery that can last for 2-3 days..

The phone itself is great but pray you never have to deal with LG's support.  I had a hardware problem with my phone within the first month that made it necessary to send the phone to LG for warranty replacement.  They held the phone for a week and a half before sending me a new one and when I got it it was for a different provider so it wouldn't activate on the Sprint network.  After three and a half weeks of getting nowhere with LG Sprint finally replaced the phone for free even though I didn't pay for the protection plan.  The agents at LG were dismissive and even laughed at me when I told them how I almost lost my job because I couldn't be reached by phone.  They'll also reject and delete any negative reviews you post on their page to keep their reviews positive.  I just received a rejection email this morning to my negative review.  Normally I'd say paying for the carriers protection plan is a waste of money but it's worth it in this case if only to avoid dealing with LG directly.  
 
In the end Sprint came though with a brand new G4 that's working great so far, no thanks to LG.

Hi guys.
 
I had this phone since Monday. got it from a telco in our place. all i can say is this...the phone is superb. for those who are having concerns about battery life, here are some tips i got from the internet to maximize it:
 
1. Lower down the brightness level of the phone. I set it 35-50% only coz the display is so bright at 100% that you wont need set it at that point.
 
2. GPS - instead of setting it at "HIGH ACCURACY", I set it at "Battery Saving" so i caan use the battery life on some other apps that I use more often.
 
3. I also removed "Auto Sync" for all the emails and other accounts that I have connected to my phone. Though for some, it will be more important that they get the emails immediately.
 
4. 
 
Here are some things I can say about this: 
- very good screen resolution 
- i ahve also experienced heating, especially when i first had it and setting up everything i need in the phone. i downloaded apps simultaneously, maybe that explains the heating. Anyway, I experienced that same with my Iphone 5. Worst, i experience the heating in my Iphone 5 during calls. 
- No lags...as in..i forgot i opened a couple of apps. and they are all working in the background. and yet i have not seen it lag. 
- its nice to hold. its not heavy. fits just right in the hand. I had huawei g610 before. dont get me wrong that phone too is superb when it comes to performance, but its too heavy for me. i usually experience tiredness of the hand when i am using it. But this LG G4, gosh i have it in my hand most of the time and no feeling of "ngawit" 
- call sounds are good. 
- fast browsing capabilities. i dont know how lg does this but i had 2 phone simultaneously browse a certain site, LG G4 opened the site faster.
 
I am kind of satisfied with this phone. I am not sure about some who had bad experiences with the phone.
 
Overall: SATISFIED!

The device runs perfectly fine with a 3000mAh battery. looking at my phone right now the battery is sitting at 75%, my previous phone the Xperia Z2 would at this time of the day with the same features enabled be sitting at about 60-62% life left.  
But to be totally fair its possible the G4 might have had even more battery left but since it is new I have been playing with it a bit more.

Have always loved my Xperia cellphones and have had many of the available models, however I decided that as of late Sony seems to only upgrade the internals of their flagship phones with majority of their current models all looking the same. And so comes the LG G4, I did alot of research on this device and my choices were this time ultimately between the LG G4 and the Samsung S6 Curve and unfortunately for my needs the G4 excelled for my needs. If a phone is going to be sealed with a non-removable battery then it needs to be waterproof but since neither the Samsung nor the LG is waterproof this was a deciding factor. That coupled to the fact that Samsung featured non expandable storage made the LG G4 a clear winner in my books. That coupled with the fact that the G4 is a overall bigger phone (easier for my big hands) and having a removable/replaceable battery just strengthens my decision.
 
Ultimately I chose the G4 and couldnt be happier with my choice. The phone with its premium leather back feels of such high quality, some will say "but the S6 comes with a glass back" but I have experienced this with my various Xperia models and with the amount of fingerprints that feature on the rear of the phone coupled with all the scratches that the glass receives from placing it on various surfaces to me its of no use whatsoever, and the G4 I can chop and change my back covers to suite my style and mood without problem.
 
Would I recommend the G4 absolutely, "but the Samsung S6 has wireless charging", with a $7 pad I bought off ebay so now does my G4, a minor in comparison to the overall price difference between the G4 and S6.  
Thank you LG for doing it right.

Just a question, are you sure this issue is not network related? I have had a similar issue with my Xperia Z1 whereby calls go straight to voicemail even though Im holding the phone in my hand. 
 
Another issue that Ive picked up on "Vodacom" when I dialled my own number it rings a good few times on the line but my actual phone does not ring, then after say the 4th ring it goes quiet on the line for a second and almost sounds like it is starting to ring again and only then does my actual phone start to ring. I researched and according to "Vodacoms" bullsh#t excuses this is when they are relaying the call between 3G and LTE. The problem is your phone ends up ringing once or twice where the caller has been waiting for you to answer for some time.

Hey guys,  
I have been saving money for a new phone. However, after a few weeks of reading reviews, opinions, video watching, etc. I'm currently lost. The phones that I had an eye on were Samsung Galaxy S6, Sony Xperia Z3 Plus, HTC One M9 and LG G4.
 
I have manged to shorten the list to HTC One M9 and the LG G4. Reason is, for me the Galaxy S6 lacks a SD card and the 64/ 128 GB versions are way expensive. I have tested a Sony Xperia Z3 and the battery life is amazing. However, according to reviews, the Sony Xperia 3 Plus has overheating issues. I bought this phone and the HTC One M9. I compared the LG G4 with the Blackberry Z3o, Classic, HTC One M9, and iPhone 5S. Gotta say the Camera rocks! Pictures are so crisp and video is excellent! just like the HTC. The music player quality sounds superb, specially the customer and surround sound options on the EQ. Personally find the music quality better than the iPhone and Blackberry music player, and the HTC did not have a music equalizer. Only thing I did not like at first was the volume and lock keys on the back but quickly got used to them. The display is brilliant like the iPhone's display and better than the Blackberry's or the HTC. The G4 got really hot just like the HTC, mind you these phones are only a few hours old.. but to be honest the heat didnt bother me. Typing on this phone is really easy. Keyboard feels decent. I find the keyboard on the Blackberry Z30 (and Z10) just way smoother, and second would be the iPhone. The processor is very smooth on the G4 just like the HTC but Youtube tends to lag a bit nothing bad at all just a few like lags... The Blackberry browser is the best, second I would say Safari, followed by Chrome. The HTC seemed to be the more dominant processor much smoother. Despite the HTC and G4 being droids, they both have a completely different feel from one another. You can't go wrong with either. I quickly fell in love with the G4!! This phone rocks!!

I'm based in the UK. This is an excellent phone - camera, screen BUT if you use high quality IEM headphones ( I use custom moulded ACS T1's) you can clearly hear the modulation interference and noise referred to in the review. Especially in orchestral music it's pretty ruinous at low levels. You may not notice on big can headphones but if you use audiophile grade IEMs you will end up, very sadly like me, taking it back for a refund. I'm back using a 2012 Samsung S3 which has no noticeable modulation ( a little machine noise but that's heavenly in comparison). I'm an android fan but Applle still seem to make the best isolated headphone jacks that keep modulation to a minimum.  My old iPhone 4 has none. The Samsung S5 has modulation issues as does their S tablet. The Sony z3 is good but the Z3+ is a pretty awful follow up. I don't want to go back to IOS and no OTG USB use so resisting iPhone S6 but listening to it there is practically no issues in sound via headphones vs LG G4. Sad but true for me.

I've had the LG G4 for about 3 days. And I have to say it's a pretty good phone.
Camera: The camera on this phone is extordinary it's phenomenal. I'm low light it does well and the colors are pretty accurate. The front facing camera is a really good camera too. It fits everybody in the shot and the picture looks amazing.
Speed: This phone is fast but I do find a little bit of lag here and there but it's rare for this phone to lag. Like when I'm done dowloading and app and it adds it to the home screen it lags for one second then it's smooth again.
Speaker: This speaker is loud when I played music and left it in a room and closed the door you could still hear it clearly through the door.
Looks: This phone looks and feels amazing. I have the black leather back one and it feels good the buttons on the back whick is super useful. I often get people looking at the phone in public and when my friends try to turn the phone on they don't know how to. Which is funny.
Battery life: The battery life is ok. This is supposed to be a 3000 mah Battery but it doesn't feel like one. This morning I unluged it with 100% battery and at 5:00 that's when it started

My first android phone was the HTC Nexus One, and being a step up from a Samsung slide phone, it blew my mind, the amount of customization and the sheer amount of feature now available to me. 
 
My current phone was the LG G3, which i love, but after the latest Android update it started to feel a bit sluggish. 
 
I got an LG G4 a few weeks ago with the INFINIM bluetooth headset and i love them both.
 
Firstly, the design is great, fantastic looking phone. Its slightly taller than the G3, and when held side by side it makes the G3 look a bit chubby. 
 
The screen is one of the standout feature for me, a watch a lot of videos on my phone, and have never used a better screen for media. Videos and pictures alike are crisp and vivid.
 
The second feature i would deem to be standout is the rear camera. I'm not a great photographer, so all of the manual features it has are admittedly wasted on me, and when i did try and use them i found the amount of settings a little daunting, but the auto settings take fantastic shots on the fly, with a burst mode built in. 
 
I found the UI to be slicker than on the G3, and while before the G3 I'd steered clear of phones running anything other than vanilla android, i found the G3 a nice surprise, until the Android 5.0 update at least. 
The UI on the G4 seems like a refinement of this, and now seems to have no issues running Android 5+.
 
As with the G3, im a huge fan of the removable battery storage and back. I carry a spare battery around with me, and have a 32gb sd card i use for media. My only issue with this was that the stock, grey back that came with the phone was too smooth, but this is easily remedied with a cover or changing the back plate,(i plan on getting a leather one).
 
TL:DR 
In all this is probably the best android phone I've had to date, the camera and screen are fantastic, the battery life is better than the last few phones I've had by quite a way, and the UI is very slick
Yes it has good features like camera sd card slot and large screen.

Yes, welcome to Android. I also had a Windows Phone, a Nokia Lumia 900 on contract. It was my first touchscreen phone, so I was quite impressed with it, and I loved the camera. After about 2 years I paid cash for a Sony Xperia E1, just to see if I would like Android. And I must say, I prefer the Android OS to Windows Phone, and there are just so many more apps and games available for Android. Here at work, we have an iPhone 5 which we use for business calls. But after a few months of playing around on the iPhone, I find it boring compared to Android. I currently have a ZTE Blade G Lux, which I got as a birthday present. It's far from being a great phone, but it will do until I get an LG G4. And the main reason I'll be getting the G4 is because it's currently the best camera phone. On YouTube it's been compared to a $4000 Canon DSLR, and there was a camera comparison on Phone Arena where the G4 was put against the Galaxy S6, HTC One M9, Xperia Z3, iPhone 6+, and a few other phones, and people rated the G4 as having the best camera. It might not be the best phone for gaming, considering there are phones out there which have a better GPU. But I think it will run most games just fine. But like I say I'll mainly be getting it for the camera, and I like the brown leather back.

Welcome to Andriod :-) I've been using Andriod for almost 3 years now and I never want to go back to iOS. It's a boring OS, in my experience. My mum uses iPhone 6 and my wife uses LG G3. I use HTC One M8. You'll get used to Andriod over time. You may find it annoying when you're prompted to select which app to use (e.g. phone dailer, web browser, message, gallery, etc.) initially, but you'll start to appreciate it when you know how Andriod works. Basically, it gives you freedom to choose which app to use. Once you've selected an app, the OS will remember and won't ask you again, unless you install other apps within the same category.

Hello Everyone!
 
I bought this phone and have been using it for more than 2 weeks now. My original plan was to wait for the 2015 Nexus 5 (My dream phone) but then i can't wait, and the G4 was available so i got this one instead. Here's my review.
 
Design/Size: 
I got the black leather for the back cover, and it looks and feels really, really, really nice. It has a harder material compared to the red and brown one, which feels more leathery. I have been reading that some have bought their phones with an extra back cover. I wonder why that is not the same in my country. :( My only problem with the back panel which i did not realize before, is that it's very annoying to use it on a table because it's curved. The front panel is very simple and looks boring when the screen is off. 
The size is a bit bigger for me. It's hard to text in one hand, but possible, there is an option in the settings to help you with this. I would prefer 4.8 to 5.2 inches phone - Nexus 5 :(

 
Interface: 
Well, this is my first android, i had a windows phone and an ipad, so i know what a smooth interface looks like. well, the first days the G4 runs very smoothly, the swipe is all like butter. but after a week, after i have installed most of the apps. i am experiencing some lags especially in the home screen after i have unlocked it from the lock screen. it's not a major lag guys, just a bit of stuttering, but like what i said, i have been using windows phone and an ipad and both really runs almost perfectly smooth, so i can't help to compare. And I am not sure if this natural in android phones. I hope someone could enlighten me about this. Anyway, about the apps, they work perfectly fine. I am playing a lot of ufc and asphalt and the games run very nice without problems.
 
Battery: 
Not very good. not very bad. the first few days, since i have been setting up my phone, always downloading apps, it will only last for like to 6 hours. if i'm not using it a lot, it could last maximum of 20 hours. so basically i have to charge like 1.2 times a day. A good thing though is that they provided me with a free battery kit. it's very useful. but i am concerned if it is fine to always remove the back cover. and if it is healthy to the phone to only charge in the battery kit.
 
Display: 
the display is superb. better than my girlfriend's ip6+. but a bit worse than my friend's S6 edge. 
 
Camera: 
Now this is a winner. No doubt. The best I have ever experienced. If you are for the camera, go for this. This phone takes selfies like it's from the rear camera. and takes photos/vids using the rear one almost like it's a dslr cam.
 
Software: 
Again this is my first android, so i am loving the way i can customize everything. the LG software is good, but some apps seems useless but at least they're not forcing me to use them. and it's quite annoying that i need to choose which apps to use either from google or lg. I am already feeling regrets that i did not wait for the nexus 5.
 
Other PROs: 
-nice earphones! 
-there is a free LG 32GB SD card. so having a 64GB is really awesome. 
-cheaper than other flagships
 
I'm tired of typing so i need to end this. In summary, this phone is really a flagship and in competition with other smartphones. One of the best. I can't say it's best in all aspects but this phone is really worth the price. Go buy it!

I have had the G4 for over 10 days now and wanted to leave a honest review on the phone. 
 
Firstly lets get straight to the camera (on which the phone was predominantly advertised on).The camera easily beats any camera I have used, and that includes the Samsung S6. In normal light it brings a great clear picture, and has manual mode with ISO, shutter and white balance settings to really play about with your picture. This camera really shines in low light. It brings out a crisp pictures and does it without making the picture look unnatural. Best camera out there.
 
Secondly I wanted to go onto performance. It has no problems with daily use. I have even downloaded Modern Combat, Asphalt 8 and Mortal Kombat X to test the phone and it plays these games with ease.
 
Battery life easily last me a day and thats with moderate/high use. That includes bluetooth to stream music to my car, phone calls, whatsapp, text messaging, social media and watching a few random YouTube videos a day. 
 
I currently have the grey metallic one and the phone generally has good ergonomics but I think the leather one will be the one to get as it has a more premium feel.

For browsing: G4 - 474 mins - 3000mAh = 9.48 sec/mAh S6 - 656 mins - 2550mAh = 15.44 sec/mAh Don't forget S6 is doing this with double brightness and higher performance. For video: G4 - 443 mins - 3000mAh = 8.86 sec/mAh S6 - 732 mins - 2550mAh = 17.22 sec/mAh Now, make your own decision. The facts give you obvious picture, it's not something to argue about.

As it seems LG G4's Camera is very very good as per reviews. Well my Good Wishes to LG for this accomplishment. But one thing is constantly agitating my mind and is bit challenging my understanding of Optics. How come simply by opening up aperture a bit more at f/1.8 compared to f/1.9 and f/2.0 that of other flagships can lead to good quality of the Photographs. As opening the aperture more simply lets more marginal rays to enter thus may let these extreme marginal rays to have a different focal length...ostensibly no lens system can claim to 100% correct in terms of sphercal aberration. A wider aperture leads to loss in depth of field i.e why generally apertures above f/2.0  to f/2.8 are preferred. I may be wrong in my assessment as I hear that the quality of images by G4 are really very very good. 
...anybody can have much wider aperture , not a big deal...  there may be something else. 
  ..but  my  G3 is also giving me good results in photography.

In our still photo tests, the LG G4 and Galaxy S6 both did excellent when taking landscape shots with both phones showing much detail and quality even when cropped.   The only minor difference again here was that the LG G4 seemed to reproduce more real colors while S6 was a bit more on the warm side for brighter colors.  Again, these differences were fairly minor and depending on your personal preference, you might like the G4 or the S6.  When the photos were cropped to more than 10X, the LG G4 seemed to have just a tad more clarity and detail, this may be due to the faster F1.8 lens vs. F1.9.

G4 VS S6 camera  
For 4K recording, we did a bunch of tests with the phones on tripod and handheld.  With the phones on tripod, the LG G4 and Galaxy S6 both did very well in capturing a lot of detail with brilliant colors.  The LG G4 seemed to have slightly better color reproduction while the Galaxy S6 exaggerated bright colors like yellow, red, and green.   In low-light, both did well but the color difference was more exaggerated, the G4 picked up much truer colors than the Galaxy S6 in our beach scene where G4 showed the true pink colors of sunset while S6 turned them yellow.
 
Also for OIS(Optical Image Stabilization) tests, LG G4 seemed to be a bit more stable with less shakes in our panning tests when viewed with 600% zoom.  Of course, the differences are actually very minor but LG G4 does seem to have a better handle on video stabilization.

Take Your Best Shots 
Camera performance with the G4 has been enhanced in several significant ways: Resolution, sharpness, speed and versatility have all been improved, and with them, every image you capture and share.

Youve got it all under control 
Manual Mode 
Go full auto and snap away as usual, or shoot like a pro and fine tune every exposure with advanced controls typically reserved for DSLR cameras. Whether you thoughtfully consider every setting and detail or simply point and shoot, images shot on the G4 look better because they simply are better.

Capture the light 
f/1.8 low light lens
 
The lens on the G4  the first of its kind in the US with f/1.8 aperture1  has an exceptionally large aperture to give you faster shutter speeds and sharper, clearer images in almost any light; from bright and sunny days on the beach to dimly-lit nights on the town.

See the Quality in Quantity 
16 MP 1/2.6 image sensor
 
The math of mobile photography is pretty simple: more pixels, more detail, more impact. With its large, high-performance sensor, the G4 gives you more than ever before, so details can be captured with greater precision, even when zoomed in.

See Truer Colors 
Color spectrum sensor
 
The Color Spectrum Sensor on the new G4 helps to achieve more accurate color and reproduction with improved white balance. Now, when you snap a photo, you can be sure that what you saw is what you got.

Life Moves Pretty Fast 
Laser auto focus & optical image stabilization
 
The G4 moves fast too. The rear camera can take a shot with just a quick double-tap of the rear button. Laser Auto Focus helps the camera to focus in an instant, even in low light. Optical image stabilization is also now better than ever too, so you get more crystal-clear images with less worry about camera shake.

Better video, by its very definition 
Ultra high definition video capture
 
Pictures may be worth a thousand words, but videos worth much, much more, especially when you record with the G4 in ultra high-definition. The G4 even lets you send 4K content from your G4 to your HDMI-enabled TV.2

Its Time For A Little Selfie Improvement 
8 MP / Gesture Control / Selfie Light
 
LG has elevated the art of the selfie with the new G4. With an 8 MP front-facing camera good enough to be a rear-facing camera and a soft selfie light that brightens around the border of the photo preview window, it perfectly captures your most important subject: you.
 
Gesture Shutter make shooting even easier. To start the photo timer, simply open your hand then make a fist. Want to capture photos in a sequence? Open and close your fist twice for four selfies in a row. Gesture View can even switch between image capture and picture review automatically when you bring the phone down then back up.

I was watching the live presentation of LG G4. LG is the only smartphone in the world which can identify calling numbers name from  own contacts if the calling number comes with different formats. For example if I get call from a real number with code as +8801713030900 ( not real number) is a number stored in my contacts as Mr.Fox, because of VOIP may be the calls will reach in my phone as +1713030900, part of original number. In this case iPhone will show a call from USA, Samsung and all others will show only the numbers, only LG with these kind of situation will show that this call is from Mr.Fox as stored in my contacts. This is only because of the UI of LG which reads the incoming numbers from end and matches with available contacts. About all other manufacturers with stock android, Blackberry, Windows, IOS reads numbers from right side, that is beginning, so they fail to identify contacts" names. LG has another thing in their telephony-it shows third party's call waiting, Samsung S6 shows that also, iPhone-- never. I use my mobile as best calling equipment first, and no other manufacturer could surpass LG G3. Now LG G4 will undoubtedly be the best phone for professional users as photographers like 1DX Canon or Hasselblad, Car lovers like Rolls. G4 will be the king. SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA 
LG Innotek (CEO Lee Woong-beom) has developed a high-performance camera module surpassing the limitations of smartphone cameras. 
 
The company announced that it has begun mass production of both a rear camera setup comprised of a 16 megapixel primary shooter with optical image stabilization (OIS) and an aperture of f/1.8 and an 8-megapixel front-facing camera module from early this month.  
 
The first use of this new camera sensor will be in the LG G4 that will be unveiled later this month.
 
This new 16 megapixel OIS camera module with an aperture of f/1.8 has the best specifications that anyone can find on smartphone cameras in the domestic market. 
 
The aperture equates to the brightness of photos taken with the camera lens. A smaller aperture will let more light into the shot, which equates to brighter and clearer images in poor lighting conditions. Even for DSLR camera lenses, an aperture of f/1.4 to 2.8 is a high-quality product.  
 
Also, the camera module receives enough light in short period of time so that the images will be less blurry. This is largely because one can reduce the time needed to hold the smartphone still when taking a photo. 
 
In order to maximize the amount of light for image sensors, LG Innotek used a high-precision, large-diameter module structure. The company doubled the size of its lenses and increased the sensing layers to six. 
 
LG Innotek is also mass producing the 8 megapixel front-facing camera module, which is the highest among the front-facing cameras in the domestic market. 
 
The product comes with a 0.11 mm ultra-thin glass blue filter. The blue filter ensures natural and accurate expression of color by keeping infrared rays from entering the camera lens and increasing the penetration of visible rays.

LG Innotek Develops Its Widest Aperture Camera Module
 
LG Innotek Brings Brighter and Clearer Solutions to Smartphones
 
Seoul, Korea, Apr. 09, 2015  LG Innotek, a leading global components and materials manufacturer, announced the development of a groundbreaking 16MP camera module with an aperture of f/1.8, making it LG Innotek's widest aperture camera developed for a smartphone. The advanced camera module began mass production at LG Innotek's plant this week and will be unveiled to consumers for the first time in the LG G4 later this month.
 
The advanced design of the camera module means that it receives 80 percent more light than in the highly praised camera found on the LG G3. More light means better looking images in low light environments and less blur when shooting action and fast moving objects. Large apertures on smartphone cameras has been challenging to develop due to the complexity and size of developing modules that must fit in the very limited space of today's smartphones.
 
Furthermore, in response to the explosive growth of selfies, LG Innotek developed an 8MP front-facing camera module, its highest resolution for a front camera to date. This high resolution module's ultra-thin IR filter keeps infrared light from entering the camera lens, giving images taken with the front camera more natural and accurate colors. The 0.11mm thin filter is roughly half the thickness of competing IR filters.
 
"At LG Innotek, we are constantly working to ensure that the cameras we develop allow users to capture and preserve the moments that are most special to them," said Ung-beom Lee, CEO of LG Innotek. "We are extremely excited to see our technology in LG's next flagship smartphone because we believe that the power, precision and operability of our camera module will clearly make an impression on consumers."

LG TO GIVE OUT 4,000 G4 SMARTPHONES AS PART OF CONSUMER EXPERIENCE CAMPAIGN PRIOR TO LAUNCH
 
Consumers in 15 Countries Given the Chance to Try LG's New Flagship Smartphone and Share Their Experiences Online
 
SEOUL, April 8, 2015 ― As part of its most ambitious smartphone introduction yet, LG Electronics (LG) will select 4,000 consumers in 15 countries who will "test drive" the all new LG G4 smartphone weeks before its official launch. Kicking off today in Korea, the program will target consumers in the following 14 other markets in the days ahead: Turkey, Indonesia, Singapore, United States, China, India, Brazil, Canada, United Kingdom, France, Germany, Mexico, Japan and Hong Kong.
 
Participants will be selected from applicants based on their entry responses (selection criteria may vary in each market). Individuals can increase their chances of being selected by sharing their application experience on social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter and Weibo. Once selected, participants in each country will be given an LG G4 for up to 30 days to experience its unique design and features, including its personalized UX, high performance camera and impressive display for sharing online. Participants will be given various assignments to carry out over the course of their experience with prizes awarded.
 
"Customers are our best fans and we think this would be an exciting and unique way to get our most important mobile product of the year close to the public," said Juno Cho, president and CEO of LG Electronics Mobile Communications Company. "We're putting the success of LG G4 in the hands of consumers before the launch because we believe they are the best judge of a great user experience, beyond just benchmarks and speed tests."
 
Interested consumers in participating markets are encouraged to check the local LG web page and social media sites in the coming days for more details on how to participate.
